page.title: 04Chew Stoke
page.content: The name Chew Stoke is derived from the River Chew & the Saxon stockade or cattlehold. This area was given by "The Conqueror" to{Gilbert Fitzturold} and is enters in the Domesday Book as {Chiwe stock.}This Fitzturold plotted against the King so his lands were seized and later came to the{St. Loe} family whose coats of arms are on the walls of the Rectory - probably the old manor. The High Street, reputed to be the smallest in England consists of 2 rows of modernised cottages now occupied on one side by Council tenants it extends from the old pack horse bridge over the river Chew towards the Church. Housing in the area varies from primitive cottages to large detached houses in select developments such as Quarry Hay. The asking price for modernised old houses of character with land is Â£135,000.
